issues.description: The UML/problem statement defines the Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int) and openValve(). In the solution repository, Pneumatic declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure() (i.e. it uses releasePressure instead of openValve). The concrete classes in the solution (LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster) implement openValve(), so the solution as provided is internally inconsistent and does not match the problem UML. This mismatch in the interface method name/signature will confuse students about which method to declare/implement and prevents the provided solution from compiling without edits.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Pneumatic interface consistent with the UML/problem statement by declaring void openValve() (and keep void raisePressure(int)). Remove or replace releasePressure() in the solution. Then ensure all implementations (LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster) implement openValve(). Alternatively, if releasePressure() was intended, update the problem statement/UML and task descriptions to specify releasePressure() instead of openValve(). Aligning names across problem, template and solution will resolve the inconsistency.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML defines the Pneumatic interface with an abstract method openValve(): void, but the solution implementation declares releasePressure() instead of openValve() in Pneumatic. The concrete classes in the solution (LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster) implement/override openValve(), creating a mismatch between the interface and its implementations. This naming divergence between the problem UML and the solution code will confuse students (they are told to implement/openValve) and may cause compilation or mapping issues because the interface and implementations do not agree on the method name.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Either (A) rename releasePressure() in Pneumatic to openValve() in the solution (and keep the classes' openValve() overrides), or (B) change the UML/problem statement to use releasePressure() and update the concrete classes to implement releasePressure() instead of openValve(). Preferred fix: change Pneumatic in the solution to declare void openValve() (and remove or alias releasePressure()) so the interface matches the UML and the implementing classes.
